Market.  With a proven firm that knows how to market crypto.  There has been nothing but callous mismanagement of marketing and PR. A fully functioning product with real use, not theoretical use-cases, is the only thing that will allow Iota to escape from the hole it has dug.

If the foundation stopped today, the project is unquestionably dead.  This is because there is nothing delivered and no external excitement to keep it going.  Finish what you've started before launching into something additional.  Focus.  

Any real delivery of an actual fully released product that is actually used in the real world is absolutely critical.  This is an existential moment for the project.  If there are any more missteps or delays, I see zero chance that it succeeds.  

The past five-plus  years of work can produce something revolutionary, or just be that thing that gave some good ideas for other projects to copy to produce a different, working product in the future, while your investors lose literal millions trying to support and believe in your mismanaged vision.

Most people nowadays like to use smartphones, especially when showcasing something.
Almost everyone has them, people are comfortable using them, they're convenient because almost anyone can immediately try out something you've just demonstrated or talked about. You can demonstrate how easy it can be to send some funds feelessly, vote on a proposal, even mint a new token and share it with your inner circle of friends. Or even create (mint) a new token within minutes and share it with people attending a conference you're currently presenting at or attending. Showcase how you can do it almost effortlessly with just your mobile phone, withing minutes, using very few funds and it could have a great networking and marketing effect.
Sadly, mobile Firefly features seem to be lagging behind the desktop wallet(s) and they could be the best marketing tool used to attract new people to the ecosystem and introduce them to our great community.

column38:
I think IOTA should focus on their core strengths, communicate better when advancements have been made, and find a better balance between trying to create hype and simply letting the project speak for itself. 

I would like IOTA to market itself as a serious and "grown up" project. Of course the project is still in the development phase, but if IOTA can compete for and champion institutional and industrial use cases then perhaps there's no need to try to go toe to toe with the thousands of other crypto projects essentially doing the same thing.

Maybe it makes more sense to market IOTA not so much as a crypto solution, but more directly its use cases when they come to fruition (EBSI, digital identities, Project Alvarium). It seems to me the crypto community at large is at a stage where the vast majority of people have picked their project which they will stand behind no matter what. Rightly or wrongly, I get the impression that for current crypto market participants IOTA isn't taken seriously as a project with a bright future due to reasons in the past. Trying to appeal to that crowd and changing their mind might be a losing battle, or put differently, it's not worth portraying IOTA as a competitor to many hyped projects whether it be through flashy NFTs or trying to appeal to the (seemingly) marginal (future) technological advantages over other DLTs. While many of IOTA's potential features might well be a game changer, such as lack of fees etc, they might not be a big enough difference at first glance to convince the average crypto user to turn their backs on their currently supported crypto, especially given IOTA's reputation for lofty promises without much to show for it. 

I think the IOTA Foundation should focus on developing its ecosystem as a mature project for mature purposes, as pompous as that may sound. When the time's right, position/market/advertise IOTA as a technology of the future rather than just another crypto project with slightly better performance metrics. Less competing against other cryptos as a show to the current crypto investors and market, and more positioning itself as an indispensable tool/backbone of future society to the general public who aren't as crypto obsessed. 

Once the major development goals have been implemented, try to detach IOTA from many of the crypto connotations rather than chase them. If they hopefully work out, projects such as EBSI, Alvarium and others should allow IOTA to stand on its own feet, stand out and even stand apart from the crypto madness and present itself as a standard "tool" for many things, without having to emphasise its "cryptoness". Don't chase the hype, set the standard.
